title: Trump Says Son of Osama bin Laden Killed in U.S. Operation
text:
An image from an undated video made available by the Central Intelligence Agency shows Hamza bin Laden reportedly during a wedding ceremony

President Trump said that Hamza bin Laden, a son of al Qaeda founder Osama bin Laden, had been killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation.

The president said in a statement released by the White House Saturday that the death of Hamza bin Laden, who was viewed by some as a rising figure in his late father’s violent Islamist group, deprives al Qaeda "of important leadership skills and the symbolic connection to his father, [and] undermines important operational activities of the group.”

U.S. officials said in July that Hamza bin Laden was believed to have died. The president didn’t confirm the reports at the time.

Mr. Trump said Hamza bin Laden was killed in an operation in the “Afghanistan/Pakistan region” and said that he was “responsible for planning and dealing with various terrorist groups.” He didn’t provide any additional details . U.S. officials had become increasingly concerned in recent years about Hamza bin Laden’s repeated threats and calls for attacks on Americans at home and abroad as well as against U.S. allies. U.S. government and private analysts say that al Qaeda is much weaker than it was in its heyday, and less potent than its ideological rival Islamic State. But, they say, al Qaeda is still capable of inspiring terrorist attacks and has several lethal affiliates world-wide. Earlier this year, the State Department offered a reward of up to $1 million for information about him, and Saudi Arabia revoked his citizenship. Those moves followed the State Department’s imposition of sanctions against him in 2017, saying at the time that he was actively engaged in terrorism. Hamza bin Laden was believed to have been born in 1989 in Saudi Arabia and was the only known son of Osama bin Laden who was still aligned with the terrorist group behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Another son was killed along with his father in 2011 during a Navy SEAL raid on their compound in Pakistan. A third son has distanced himself from al Qaeda. Mr. Trump’s announcement confirming the death of the younger bin Laden —which was an important U.S. national security objective—comes after a string of foreign-policy stumbles over the past week. These included a furor over Mr. Trump’s plans, later canceled, to invite Afghan Taliban leaders to the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., during the week of Sept. 11 and the revelation of Oval Office arguments leading to the resignation of White House national security adviser John Bolton.
